00007 <h2>What's new?</h2>
00008 <p>
00009 [Mar. 25th 2005]
00010 "cpplapack-2005_03_25" has been released.
00011 This release contains some bug fixes and modification.
00012 See "ChangeLog" for the detail.
00013 It also contains the alpha version of sparse matrix classes (dssmatrix and zssmatrix).
00014 These classes are still so buggy, but it is OK as long as you don't use these classes in your code.
00015 </p>
00016 
00017 <p>
00018 [Oct. 15th 2004]
00019 Mr. Ueshima wrote a tutorial of CPPLapack in Japanese.
00020 "cpplapack-2004_04_24" has been released.
00021 It is very useful for beginners of CPPLapack.
00022 The HTML version is available at 
00023 <a href="http://cpplapack.sourceforge.net/tutorial/japanese/index.html">
00024 http://cpplapack.sourceforge.net/tutorial/japanese/index.html</a>,
00025 and the PDF version is available at 
00026 <a href="http://cpplapack.sourceforge.net/tutorial/japanese/CPPLapack_Tutorial-Japanese.pdf">http://cpplapack.sourceforge.net/tutorial/japanese/CPPLapack_Tutorial-Japanese.pdf</a>
00027 </p>
00028 
00029 <p>
00030 [Apr. 24th 2004]
00031 "cpplapack-2004_04_24" has been released.
00032 OpenMP macros (#pragma omp parallel for private(j,k)) 
00033 are added to all triple for-loops. 
00034 The search engine for this documentation is added.
00035 This search engine is case-sensitive.
00036 </p>
00037 
00038 <p>
00039 [Apr. 1st 2004]
00040 "cpplapack-2004_04_01" has been released.
00041 The complex double-precision matrix and vector classes 
00042 (zgematrix, zgbmatrix, zhematrix, zcovector, zrovector)
00043 are newly added.
00044 </p>

00048 <!---------------------------------------------------------------------------->
00049 <hr><hr>
00050 <h2>Introduction</h2>
00051 <p>
00052 CPPLapack is a C++ class wrapper for BLAS and LAPACK.
00053 </p>
00054 
00055 <p>
00056 The interfaces of Fortran BLAS, LAPACK, CBLAS, and CLAPACK 
00057 are not user-friendly, and induce a lot of coding mistakes 
00058 not only for LAPACK beginners but also experienced programmers. 
00059 Because of its difficult interface, BLAS functions are not widely used 
00060 for simple matrix calculations such as "+", "-", "*", and so on
00061 even though these calculations are frequently required.
00062 If there is a user-friendly library using BLAS and LAPACK in the background,
00063 it is really useful to minimize the program development time 
00064 and computational time at the same time.
00065 Existing matrix libraries, however, are not sufficient as far as we know.
00066 </p>
00067 
00068 <p>
00069 CPPLapack has a very user-friendly interface 
00070 as same as ordinary C++ matrix libraries.
00071 Moreover, CPPLapack uses BLAS and LAPACK functions in the background
00072 though programmers just need to write simple codes 
00073 such as <code>"A=B*C;"</code>, <code>"A.dgesv(y);"</code>, and so on.
00074 </p>
00075 
00076 <p>
00077 The advantage of using CPPLapack are not only user-friendly interface 
00078 and fast computational speed but also saving memory space.
00079 In case of large-size matrix calculation, 
00080 the number of copy times of objects affects required memory space
00081 and computational time materially.
00082 CPPLapack has a mechanism called "Smart-Temporary" system 
00083 to minimize the number of copy times.
00084 The "Smart-Temporary" system is also hidden in CPPLapack library 
00085 so that programmers don't need to pay any attention for this system.
00086 (CPPLapack used to employed "to_return" system.
00087 Now CPPLapack uses this system to realize the same purpose 
00088 with keeping the compatibility with old versions.)
00089 </p>
00090 
00091 <p>
00092 This program is designed for large matrix calculation.
00093 If you don't have mind to handle large matrices, 
00094 to use another matrix library is recommended.
00095 </p>
00096 
00097 <p>
00098 CPPLapack is still a beta program so far.
00099 It is a shame but there are a few bugs 
00100 and unsupported BLAS and LAPACK functions.
00101 If you are going to use CPPLapack, please be aware this situation.
00102 Of course, it is very nice if you help us to develop CPPLapack.
00103 </p>
00104 
00105 
00106 <!---------------------------------------------------------------------------->
00107 <!---------------------------------------------------------------------------->
00108 <!---------------------------------------------------------------------------->
00109 <hr>
00110 <h2>Special Features</h2>
00111 <ul>
00112 <li>
00113 User-friendly interface<br>
00114 </li>
00115 <li>
00116 Hi-speed matrix calculations using BLAS and LAPACK<br>
00117 </li>
00118 <li>
00119 Minimized number of copy times of objects using "Smart-Temporary" system<br>
00120 </li>
00121 </ul>
00122 All of the features are hidden in C++ class library 
00123 so that programmers are not required to do any special programming.
00124 
00125

00130 <h2>Where to Get</h2>
00131 <p>
00132 The official distribution site of CPPLapack is
00133 <a href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/cpplapack/">here</a>.
00134 </p>

00139 <!---------------------------------------------------------------------------->
00140 <hr>
00141 <h2>How to Install</h2>
00142 <p>
00143 Actually, you don't need to install CPPLapack.
00144 CPPLapack is a bunch of C++ header files.
00145 Just expand the package at somewhere you like, 
00146 and write a include path in your "Makefile".
00147 All you need to include is only "cpplapack.h".
00148 </p>
00149 
00150 <p>
00151 But CPPLapack needs BLAS and LAPACK written in Fortran installed. 
00152 Just make sure these two libraries are installed 
00153 and modify "Makefile" to include and link to them. 
00154 In stead of original BLAS and LAPACK packages, 
00155 bender-supplied libraries such as Intel math kernel library(MKL), 
00156 Compaq extended math library(CXML), and so on are also acceptable.
00157 </p>
00158 
00159 <p>
00160 What BLAS and LAPACK need to link depends on your platform. 
00161 Some examples of "Makefile" are prepared. 
00162 See \ref pg-makefile.
00163 </p>
00164 
00165 <p>
00166 For Cygwin users, a simple instructions on 
00167 how to install ATLAS and LAPACK is prepared. 
00168 See \ref pg-cygwin.
00169 </p>
00170 
00171 <!---------------------------------------------------------------------------->
00172 <!---------------------------------------------------------------------------->
00173 <!---------------------------------------------------------------------------->
00174 <hr>
00175 <h2>Important Specification</h2>
00176 <ul>
00177 <li>
00178 The namespace for CPPLapack is "CPPL".
00179 </li>
00180 <li>
00181 You should not and don't need to use underscored matrix classes. 
00182 These classes are not for project codes. 
00183 The underscored classes are called "Smart-Temporary" classes.
00184 The detail of "Smart-Temporary" system is explained in \ref pg-nt.
00185 </li>
00186 <li>
00187 The numbering system of the matrix component is NOT 1-based but 0-based.
00188 In case of m x n matrix,
00189 the element number at the upper left is (0,0),
00190 and the element number at the lower right is (m-1,n-1).
00191 See \ref pg-bandmatrix for information of a band matrix.
00192 </li>
00193 <li>
00194 The matrix arrays are stored in column-major style. 
00195 although most of C programmers like to use row-major style. 
00196 This is because of the conventional Fortran LAPACK style.
00197 </li>
00198 <li>
00199 The matrix and vector member objects m, n, l, and array are the const reference objects so that they can be used to obtain the data but cannot be overwritten.
00200 </li>
00201 <li>
00202 LAPACK member functions implemented in CPPLapack, such as A.dgesv(y), overwrite the matrix A.
00203 When you need to keep the original matrix A, you have to make a copy of the matrix A before using LAPACK member functions.
00204 </li>
00205 <li>
00206 For easy debugging, "CPPL_VERBOSE" and "CPPL_DEBUG" macros are prepared. 
00207 When "-DCPPL_VERBOSE" is specified in compilation commands, every called function outputs its function name to stderr.
00208 When "-DCPPL_DEBUG" is specified in compilation commands, matrix bounds checking are enabled. 
00209 We recommend you to enable these macros during the program testing, 
00210 then recompile codes without these macros for CPPLapack's best performance.
00211 </li>
00212 <li>
00213 It is important NOT to leave out the returned object. 
00214 The calculated and returned object must be substituted to an object. 
00215 For example, <code>A+B;</code> is not good. 
00216 For another example, when 
00217 <code>"dcovector f(const dcovector&amp; x){ return 2*x; }"</code>,
00218 <code>f(x);</code> is also not good. 
00219 These are because of the "Smart-Temporary" system. 
00220 See \ref pg-nt. 
00221 </li>
00222 </ul>
00223 
00224 <!---------------------------------------------------------------------------->
00225 <!---------------------------------------------------------------------------->
00226 <!---------------------------------------------------------------------------->
00227 <hr>
00228 <h2>Test Programs</h2>
00229 Test programs to check the operations are there in "test" directory.
00230 They are also easy examples for you to learn how to use CPPLapack.
00231 
00232 <!---------------------------------------------------------------------------->
00233 <!---------------------------------------------------------------------------->
00234 <!---------------------------------------------------------------------------->
00235 <hr>
00236 <h2>Benchmark Programs</h2>
00237 <p>
00238 Some programs to estimate the speed of CPPLapack are prepared 
00239 in "benchmark" directory.
00240 </p>
00241 
00242 <p>
00243 The performance of CPPLapack is almost the same as the performance of original BLAS and LAPACK.
00244 However, some of arguments of BLAS and LAPACK functions such as ALPHA, BETA, TRANS, and so on are fixed at certain values.
00245 When you want to make the full-use of BLAS and LAPACK functions, you can call their functions directory in codes of CPPLapack as usual.
00246 </p>
00247 
00248 <!---------------------------------------------------------------------------->
00249 <!---------------------------------------------------------------------------->
00250 <!---------------------------------------------------------------------------->
00251 <hr>
00252 <h2>FAQ</h2>
00253 <p>
00254 (Q)I found my program using CPPLapack consuming the memory larger and larger
00255 in a loop. Why does this happen?
00256 <br>
00257 (A)Most likely, you leave out some returned matrix or vector object in the loop.
00258 Please read "Important Specification" section carefully.
00259 </p>
00260 
00261 
00262 <p>
00263 (Q)When I print components of a matrix or vector, 
00264 I sometimes see "nan" printed. What is the possible reason?
00265 <br>
00266 (A)First of all, please make sure that your objects are initialized.
00267 The constructor with size arguments such as 
00268 <code>"CPPL::dgematrix A(5,10);"</code>
00269 does NOT initialize its array components.
00270 The "resize" function does NOT initialize, neither.
00271 Please initialize objects using substitutions, 
00272 or use "identity" or "zero" function to initialize them.
00273 </p>
00274
